artist: Constant; Modeler: Copy after Louis-Simon Boizot; Manufacturer: Formerly attributed to Sèvres Porcelain Factory
creditline: Gift of Mr. and Mrs. Leo A. Hodroff
life_date: Constant, French, active 1783–1809; Copy after Louis-Simon Boizot, Modeler, French, 1743–1809; Formerly attributed to Sèvres Porcelain Factory, Manufacturer, Paris, 1756–present
text: Porcelain production was still guarded as a trade secret in this era, yet enterprising manufacturers stole production methods and winning designs. “Constant,” a mysterious porcelain maker in Paris, frequently copied models produced by the Sèvres Porcelain Factory, which employed prominent sculptors like Louis-Simon Boizot to design bisque sculptures. Constant’s copy of Boizot’s Love Stung by a Bee is simplified (missing the bees swarming the hive) and smaller. Thomas Jefferson also owned a variant of this popular design, purchased during his Paris residency, 1784–89 (Monticello, Virginia).
title: Love Stung by a Bee
